This chapter covers teleoperation (manual control) and simple autonomous movements." tags: [robot-control, teleoperation, ros2, robotics] keywords: [robot, control, teleoperation, joystick, keyboard, velocity, cmd_vel, twist] learningObjectives: - "Understand the concept of robot teleoperation." - "Learn how to control a robot using a keyboard or joystick." - "Be able to write a simple ROS 2 node to make a robot move autonomously." prerequisites: ["Gazebo Simulation Fundamentals"] outcome: "Readers will be able to control a simulated robot both manually and with a simple autonomous script." successCriteria: - "Drive a simulated robot around in Gazebo using a keyboard teleoperation node." - "Write a Python script that makes the robot drive in a square." - "Explain the structure of a `Twist` message." toolsUsed: [ROS 2, Gazebo] relatedConcepts: [robot-kinematics, velocity-control, control-theory, teleoperation] --- import Prerequisites from '@site/src/components/Prerequisites'; import LearningObjective from '@site/src/components/LearningObjective'; import Outcome from '@site/src/components/Outcome'; import SuccessCriteria from '@site/src/components/SuccessCriteria'; import Exercise from '@site/src/components/Exercise'; import Checkpoint from '@site/src/components/Checkpoint'; # Chapter 4: Basic Robot Control This chapter will cover basic robot control techniques, including teleoperation and simple movements.

You should have a simulated robot running in Gazebo and be comfortable with basic ROS 2 concepts.
  • Understand the concept of robot teleoperation.
  • Learn how to control a robot using a keyboard or joystick.
  • Be able to write a simple ROS 2 node to make a robot move autonomously.
 ## Teleoperation **Teleoperation** is the process of controlling a robot from a distance. In ROS 2, this is typically done by running a teleoperation node that reads input from a keyboard, joystick, or other device and publishes velocity commands to a topic. The standard topic for velocity commands is `/cmd_vel`, and the message type is `geometry_msgs/msg/Twist`. A `Twist` message contains two vectors: `linear` (for x, y, z velocity) and `angular` (for roll, pitch, yaw velocity). ## Simple Autonomous Movement To make a robot move on its own, you can write a ROS 2 node that publishes `Twist` messages to the `/cmd_vel` topic. By controlling the linear and angular velocities over time, you can make the robot follow a specific path. For example, to make a robot drive in a straight line, you would publish a `Twist` message with a constant positive `linear.x` value and zero for all other values. To make it turn, you would publish a message with a positive or negative `angular.z` value.

What is the name and message type of the standard ROS 2 topic for robot velocity commands?

Write a ROS 2 Python node that makes your simulated robot drive in a circle. You will need to publish a `Twist` message with a constant `linear.x` and a constant `angular.z`.

You can now make a robot move! This is a fundamental skill that you will build upon in the coming chapters.
  • Drive a simulated robot around in Gazebo using a keyboard teleoperation node.
  • Write a Python script that makes the robot drive in a square.
  • Explain the structure of a `Twist` message.
